you forgot about one thing. you mentioned that the companies are not quite accurate with the flex. however, you were putting the weights at the exact middle of the stick. different players prefer different “kickpoints” depending on the type of shots they take most. for example, a defenseman would most likely prefer a stick with a low kick point as he will be taking a lot of slapshot’s. whereas a forward would typically like the higher kickpoint as they take many snapshots and wristshots. that is where the flex should be applied to, not the middle of the stick.

An additional constraint when testing flex numbers is that sticks are built with different flex points. Generally, a defense man's stick will have a mid-flex point, where a forward will have a lower flex point. The lower flex point helps with a quicker release for shots like a wrist shot or a snap shot, where a mid flex helps with a heavy shot like a slap shot. Any flex testing would need to take this into consideration to be accurate.

There are other things to consider when choosing a stick. The flex point. Some sticks are center loaded and some are bottom loaded, your hand position usually determines your preference. Someone who keeps there bottom hand low wants a stick that loads 2/3 down the shaft, where as a guy like Chara who's bottom hand is at least half way up the shaft would use a center loaded stick.

Also adding an extension or cutting the stick changes the over all flex number, as well as the ratio of load point to stick length. I used to use and 85, but had to extend it 3 inches, it felt like a piece of rubber. Now I use a 100, with a bottom load, because Im more wrist shot than slap shot, so I want the bottom 1/3 to be the whip. I used to play hockey, and was lucky enough to get free composite prototype sticks, and give feed back to the company. I never knew how much it really mattered until I talked to the companies designing them....

SmarterEveryDay, one possible problem with the test of the flex in the video is that different sticks have a various types of flex profiles. 

Measuring two sticks that have 100 flex but different flex profiles will wield different results which would account for different ratings in your tests.

Some sticks have a lower kick where the flex of the stick is closer towards the blade of the stick. Where other sticks have a mid-kick (where the flex is near the middle) generally spread throughout the stick.

So measuring 75, 85, 100, 100 sticks requires knowledge about where the flex point is and then measuring the flex from that angle.

It's not that manufacturers don't record the proper flex, it's that each flex is calculated differently based on the type of stick. For example, a midpoint flex stick should be expected to flex like you graphed out. A stick that is designed to flex lower (low-point flex) on the shaft will flex differently if measured in the middle. Some sticks are designed to be strong on one side and weak on another. There's a lot of engineering that goes into this. Some stick makers might base their flex rating off of the "broken-in" period (the period where the stick will exhibit that flex the longest), others might base it on the brand-new period with no break-in.

Also, with hockey equipment, there is no real standardized measurements. Which is partly why you saw different flexes. Each manufacturer tends to measure things slightly different. This shows up most in goalie gear, where a 26" paddle stick in one maker is a 28.5" in another. Same goes for skate/pad sizing.

You mentioned at the end that you don't understand hockey because you don't play. Hockey player here.... You got the physics of the shot correct but nothing about the stick. The flex number on the stick corresponds to the flex in a certain kick point of the stick. Older sticks and mid kick point sticks use the middle of the stick to determine the flex number, whereas the Low kick point sticks are more towards the bottom. The "lowness" is dependent on the brand, as some are lower than others. For example the stick he used was a Warrior Covert DT1 which has a super low kick point. so you may notice the stick really doesn't flex in the middle, the bottom flings the puck. Mid kick sticks are preferred by slap shot takers because when the stick flexes in the middle the is more surface area to build up potential energy, causing more kick pack once the contact is made, increasing speed and power.

hey destin, i dont know if the guys at the rink told you or not, but there are different flex pattern designs as well as the amount of flex the stick has. some sticks like the warrior covert (the black on in the video) have a low flex point. meaning the carbon in the stick was set so the majority of the stick flexes in the lower part closer to the blade. this make the release of the puck faster or the puck is on the blade for less time. doesnt mean the puck travels fast tho. there is also a mid flex stick where the lower part by the blade and the top parts of the shaft are stiffer than the middle. allowing the shaft to load up even more so. the mid flex sticks would give you a better bow for a camera shot and the puck travels a little faster. although because it loads up more the puck stays on the blade a little longer.

I have a slight issue with using those beam deflection equations for the hockey sticks. In the beginning the player stated that his stick was a composite material. And the stick that was broken was wooden. Wood is also a composite. Those deflection equations assume homogeneous material and are not valid for composite beams. Unless you can show that in the direction stick is loaded, it will behave the same way as a homogeneous beam, your predictions will be inaccurate.

Destin,
One note on the "disproving flex number" portion of this video. Hockey sticks are made at a certain length from the factory, relatively within an inch of each other in any given batch. If the player is taller than 6'2" and prefers a longer stick, an extension can be added to the top of the stick which would actually decrease the flex number of said stick. Likewise, some players like shorter sticks, and cutting the sticks down from the top increases flex.

Otherwise, solid video - and it would be interesting to see a second part of this made with different brands and models. Bauer's Vapor line claims a "dual kick point", a mid for slap shots and a lower (like the Warrior stick used here) one for wrist and snap shots. CCM's RBZ line claims no kick point (or variable), flexing where your hand is on the stick as opposed to a predetermined point.

To whoever asked how much the stick cost that the player broke: $250 US. It's a Warrior Covert DT1 LT, an elite level stick generally used by players in juniors (QMJHL, OHL) or college hockey, both D3 and D1, or semi-pro (ECHL, WHL) and above.

When measuring the flex of the sticks, it didn't appear that you were measuring from the ends. Obviously you would exclude the foot of the stick but the difference in length of sticks for the height of the player would most likely have a large affect on how much flex the stick would have. A longer stick will always have more flex than a shorter one made from the exact same material. Perhaps this is why your ratings were off unless all of the sticks you checked were the same length.
